importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication reflects the urgency of current climate-related disasters and the ongoing global push for early-warning systems in response to extreme weather events in 2025.

The date when a mountain glacier in Switzerland was monitored and predicted to collapse, allowing evacuation of the village of Blatten, illustrates a real-time application of early warning systems in mitigating disaster impacts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The year 2025 marks a period of intensified extreme weather events, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, highlighting the global scale and immediacy of the climate crisis.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable to disaster-related deaths.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of deaths in the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.
The WMO reports that 90% of weather, water, and climate-related deaths have occurred in developing nations over the past 50 years.
While 108 countries now use multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52 in the last decade), half of 62 assessed countries still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is worst in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries developing functional websites and issuing standardized alerts.
The WMO emphasizes that early warning leads to early action and aims to empower communities globally to respond effectively.
Real-world examples such as the 2025 glacier collapse in Switzerland and evacuation of Blatten demonstrate the life-saving potential of monitoring and early warnings.
Extreme weather events are 'spiraling' due to climate change, with increasing frequency and severity globally.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The United Nations' World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has issued a global call to action to strengthen early-warning systems for extreme weather events, noting that nearly half of all countries lack such systems—particularly in developing nations. With over 2 million deaths attributed to weather, water, and climate hazards in the past 50 years, and 90% of those deaths occurring in developing countries, the WMO warns that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in nations without early warnings. Despite progress in early-warning adoption (from 52 to 108 countries in the last decade), assessments show half of 62 assessed countries still have only basic capacity. The article emphasizes that extreme weather is spiraling due to climate change, citing real-world examples such as the 2025 glacier collapse in Switzerland that allowed evacuation of Blatten, and major weather disasters in Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, and southern Europe. The WMO stresses that early warning systems are not just about alerting but empowering communities to take early action, with growing progress especially in Africa.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
